question: Linear data structures store elements sequentially, one after another.
A stack follows the First In, First Out (FIFO) principle.
An array is a fixed-size collection of elements stored in contiguous memory.
A queue allows insertion from both ends but deletion from only one end.
Non-linear data structures follow a sequential arrangement of elements.
A graph consists of nodes connected by edges.
A family tree is an example of a queue data structure.
A linked list is a collection of nodes where each node contains data and a reference to the next node.
A queue at a ticket counter follows the Last In, First Out (LIFO) principle.
A hash table is used to store key-value pairs for quick lookup.
A stack allows insertions and deletions only from the top.
A tree has a hierarchical structure where each node may have child nodes.
Graphs are used to represent relationships, such as social networks.
A queue follows the Last In, First Out (LIFO) principle.
Stacks are commonly used in function calls and undo operations.
